account tracked for their own billing but launching into one big shared V PC
so let's take a look at how this might work this is the infrastructure account
perhaps the networking team's account we've got an application which we know is going to have to be available over

subnets this is a very common design each of those subnets in different availability zones so one public and
private availability zone this V PC is going to have an Internet gateway
because one of our requirements is our application is accessible from the internet but also it's going to have a
virtual private gateway to provide access back to an on-premises network so a VPN connection or maybe Direct Connect
we're going to configure the route tables in this V PC in the way that you'd expect so for the public subnets
we're going to have a route table that says use the internet gateway and for the private subnets a route table that says let's use the virtual private
gateway this is where the interesting piece happens we use something called RAM resource access manager to now
identify and share the subnets so we're going to create two resource shares we're going to create a public subnet
resource share and a private subnet resource share we're going to choose
which of these subnets are associated with each of those shares and then we're going to make those available so in this case we're sharing both public
private for our external application it needs to be able to launch its web servers into those public subnets and
launch its back-end servers into the private subnets however our internal application team
they don't ever need to publish anything to the internet so their resource share the one that they're using only gives
them access to the private subnets so that's where they now launch their ec2 instances now those external and
internal applications are actually all being deployed inside their own accounts but actually they're being launched inside this shared V PC so what do you
see if you're the owner of one of those applications what is it you can actually see in terms of launching them
well you just see the subnets you don't actually see anything else so these subnets just look like they
exist inside your account so from the perspective of the external application it sees all four subnets and it can
launch an ec2 instance into each one of them from the perspective of the internal application it only sees the

manager and what you can do with VPC sharing so you can still take that V PC
and apply some of the other controls that we talked about before so network ACLs let's say this is now a V PC with

years ago for using ec2 instances to connect multiple V pcs together and
there's probably a fair few of you that have used the transit V PC design it uses VPN connections and virtual private
gateways to create a hub-and-spoke type setup connecting everything together but
it does have some challenges if all you want to use it for is connecting those V pcs it's pretty simple but the minute
you want to customize it you now need to manage the lambda functions behind the scenes and in terms of scale it's still
a pair of ec2 instances that you're routing your traffic through so it gets hard to scale it's hard to manage this
environment it's also quite difficult to then segment the routing within it if you only want these
three V pcs to talk to this one but your VPN connection to be shared between them all that's quite a complex configuration in
the transit V PC pattern so we took the feedback that we heard from customers around transit V PC and the pattern that
we published and we decided that we were going to build a native feature to do this and that's what transit gateway
actually is so when I say it's a native service it's built into the fabric of V PC it's the same infrastructure that's
delivering the package between your individual ec2 instances that's where transit gateway exists it uses elastic
network interfaces in each of the availability zones that you're using for your V PC so what that means is some of
those are bandwidth challenges on the transit V PC design they don't exist with transit gateway it scales
horizontally behind the scenes it uses a technology that we call hyper plane it's the same technology that exists behind
that gateway behind EFS endpoints so there are a few other services and finally it does give you
that capability to have flexible segmentation and what I mean by that is that ability to have separate route
tables and identify different behaviors for different V PCs and different VPN connections so there's a lot to take in

just say huge scale and talking about thousands of V pcs so you want to connect 4,000 V pcs together

Gateway more bandwidth you add more tunnels how does that actually work well
it uses something called ECM P so equal cost multi pathing and what that means is the more tunnels you add we will hash

get kind of up to 50 gig of connectivity easily over a VPN connection to transit gateway you do need to check that your

might choose to use private link remember is to present a service from a single V PC to other V pcs now the way

support thousands of spoke V pcs so scale is not a challenge here but
actually there's a couple of key things so you would use private link if you're sharing an individual application if you
want full network reach ability that's when you reduce transit gateway in terms
of trust you could use private link to share a service to any other AWS account it only allows them to consume that
particular service that you've published via the network load balancer whereas with transit gateway yes you have
routing domains but actually it allows full traffic flow so any ports any protocols and then you have to configure
your security groups obviously to restrict that so there is more trust involved in a transit gateway setup but
it does give you a centralized point of control you can choose who can route to each other in terms of dependencies
private link requires you to have a network globe balancer and to have very specific application architectures using
TCP whereas the transit gateway any traffic can flow so that's kind of the
balance between private link and transit gateway so I'm going to take questions

connections between each of these points of presence that we have all of those
are fully managed by AWS this is our infrastructure our network so why do we
have a backbone why do we have this in the first place well first of all from a security point of view all traffic that is moving
between our regions with the exception of China goes over the backbone if you send traffic from one public IP address
to another public IP address in to AWS regions that traffic will go across our backbone in terms of availability we
fully manage this infrastructure so from that point of view if there is maintenance happening on one of these
circuits we can take that out of service and make sure that you're not impacted by any sort of outage there so we
believe that we can ensure you have high availability for your connectivity by fully managing this backbone ourselves
managing that availability also means that we can give you consistent performance so from this perspective we
know the path that all of these packets are taking we can give you the most optimal path available between two
points on our network and then finally having the edge locations on the backbone means that we can give you the
option to get onto our network sooner so if you're using cloud front you enter our network at a cloud front pop you

and 19 new Direct Connect partners and our Direct Connect partners are key here because they're the ones who help you
connect to our Direct Connect locations when you're not located within the same facilities that we are so 19 new Direct
Connect partners is great in terms of increasing the performance for certain workloads we enabled support for jumbo
frames so you can now get a 9001 MTU from on-premises all the way through to
your V PC and also we launched capability in some of our Direct Connect
locations for the logical redundancy what this means is that you can have a physical connection and over it run two
separate bgp sessions for an individual virtual interface well that means is if we do maintenance
on one of our Reuters you still have a path via the other one it doesn't replace physical redundancy but it does
give you some options from a logical perspective also we have the integration
now with VMware on AWS so if you're connecting to multiple V pcs with Direct
Connect the kind of the traditional way you would have done this is created a private virtual interface for each of
your V pcs each one going to its own virtual private gateway for redundancy you'd put in a second Direct Connect
connection to another location and again you would send private virtual interfaces to each of your V pcs if you
wanted more bandwidth the way you can achieve this you can now use link aggregation so you could have multiple 10 gig connections so between your
router and the AWS router you can now have four tankey connections for example 40 gigabits of connectivity so at the
moment the default limit on that is for connections if you need more than that let us know we can increase that limit
for you but we also went one step further that link between a reconnect location and an individual
region that's no longer a hard link because what you can do is deploy a direct connect gateway and Direct
Connect gateway is a global object so now when we create our private virtual interfaces if we send them to a direct
connect gateway we can actually now attach up to ten virtual private gateways in different regions to the
same direct connect gateway this means that you can consume Direct Connect from a location that is near to your data
centers student to your premises and then use our backbone to carry that traffic to the remote regions looking at
how you might use that with transit gateway and so one thing you could do of course is use it in parallel so using
the older model attaching to the virtual private gateway with virtual interfaces that absolutely works fine and that's
currently what you would have to do if you want access directly into your V PC the other way you could do it is use a
public virtual interface to reach the VPN endpoints for transit gateway so the way that works when you have an AWS
region and you create a public virtual interface over Direct Connect it gives you access to all of the public IP
addresses for all of our all of our region's within those IP addresses are the endpoints for our VPN services and
that includes transit gateway so if you want to use transit gateway today with VPN connectivity over Direct Connect
that's the model that you would use in the next couple of months we'll have native support for Direct Connect on transit gateway so network services
let's just briefly talk about DNS so from a DNS perspective if you have your on-premises data center and you have a
VP see inside your VP C there is a DNS service it lives on the dot to address in your VP C however if any of you have
tried to configure perhaps an on-premises DNS server to reach that dot to address that connection it doesn't
work you cannot reach the dot to address from on-premises equally from your VP C
if you wanted to be able to forward queries from your VP C back to on-premises again that's not a
configuration that was supported so what we saw customers doing here was deploying their own DNS server on an ec2
instance in the V PC and then establishing connectivity between their on-premises and their V PC DNS server
so okay that's fine um you could do that it connects then to the dot too but then
how does this scale if you have three VP C's you have three DNS servers you have more VP C's that's even more DNS servers
so we launched a feature called route 53 resolver what this enables you to do is present a network interface for inbound
DNS queries inside your V PC and this is reachable from on-premises what this
means is you could perhaps go from running a hundred DNS forwarders down to one single endpoint now of course a
single endpoint is not a good design you're going to deploy multiple endpoints so inside your V PC you can
choose multiple availability zones to put those network interfaces in so you
could also then create rules for forwarding if you want to query your on-premises DNS using a certain set of
names you can create forwarding rules inside route 53 resolver and then you can use resource access managers to
share those with multiple VP C's they all use the same endpoints so if you're
doing a kind of large DNS setup at the moment and this looked familiar to you perhaps come and have a chat with one of
